reviewText: Fun, tragic and corny: plus Lana Turner! What more could you want. Tom Ewell is a hoot, before Marilyn in the "Seven Year Itch" Carol Burnett should have parodied it in the manner of her "Mildred Pierce" take-off

reviewText: Didn't expect much from this movie as Lana Turner isn't really  my cup of tea. More of a Joan Crawford/Bette Davis fan. But really enjoyed the movie and thought Turner quite good and believable when she'd show her hard edge. And yes, a girl like this would be attracted to Milland's goodness/unavailability.Liked ALOT her moral dilemna and really found myself on the edge of my seat whether she's succomb to the evil guy....who really was also good. And Ann Dvorak! She is a tragic hoot. A great performance by her.Yeah, the story is pretty dumb...but the performances are really good.Clothes, my particular passion....ok....Lana was a bit thick in the waste to carry them off.
summary: Must see if you like Ann Dvorak
Title: N/A

reviewText: Contrary to what some other reviewers have written, I happen to find this movie quite enjoyable and a prime example of the "Happiness At What Cost?" theme that was explored in many outstanding films of the 30's, 40's and 50's.  A few that come to mind are DODSWORTH (Walter Huston), ALL THIS AND HEAVEN TOO (Bette Davis) and THE SHINING HOUR (Joan Crawford), all of which dealt with people having to ask the question: Do I grab my one and only chance for true love, even though others may suffer for it, or do I follow the noble course of action and sacrifice my own happiness so that the feelings of others will be spared?  This film certainly doesn't measure up to any of those classics, but it's still a very entertaining drama.  The moral/ethical decision, in this case, involves lonely Lana Turner trying to choose whether to force her lover Ray Milland to leave his wife (an invalid confined to a wheelchair) or to  let him go and leave his marriage intact.  Soap opera?  Maybe, but it's great stuff to watch on a cold winter afternoon.
Title: N/A

reviewText: LET ME DIVIDE THE MOVIE IN TO PARTS.??  BUT BEFORE I DO,  I MUST REMIND THE VIEWER THAT LANA TURNER' LAST FILM BEFORE THE ONE IN QUESTION, WAS "THE THREE MUSKATEERS".  HER BEAUTY WAS ALMOST UNBELIEVABLE, IN TECHNICOLOR,,, AND THE PHOTOGRAPHER,,,, IF NOT IN LOVE WITH LANA,,,,,,,,,, SURELY MADE SURE THAT EVERY MAN THAT WOULD SEE HIS FILM WOULD FALL ...... GOOD.  I HAVE NEVER BEFORE OR SINCE, SEEN A WOMAN SO BEAUTIFULLY PHOTOGRAPHED.  HER FACE FILLED THE SCREEN, AND A LIGHT SEEMED TO GLOW FROM WITHIN.LANA TOOK A YEAR OFF TO GET MARRIED.  NOT THREE YEARS.  LANA HAD A PICTURE IN 1948,,,,,,,,,, AND 1950.  IT SEEMS THAT SHE ONLY MISSED A YEAR.  GOOD! THAT M.G.M. WANTED HER BACK TO MOVIES????????????  I AM SURE ALL HER FANS WANTED HER BACK.  HERE IT COMES!!  " A LIFE OF HER OWN".GEORGE CUKOR THE WOMANS DIRECTOR.  REALLY??  SEEMS TO ME THAT HE HELPED THE STUDIO'S GET RID OF SO MANY STARS.  I WILL TRY TO SHOW YOU WHAT I MEAN.  GARBO.  "TWO FACED WOMAN".  SHEARER.  "HER CARDBOARD LOVER".  CRAWFORD,, "A WOMANS FACE".  CUKOR HAD A TENDENCY TO SHOW OTHER ACRESSES AS YOUNGER AND MORE INTERESTING,OR MORE LOVINGLY PHOTOGRAPHED.  I WOULD RATHER NOT GO IN TO CUKOR'S LIFE, ONLY HIS JUDGEMENT.  REMEMBER CUKOR "TRIED" TO HELP GARLANDS CAREER.  THE CUTS TO "A STAR IS BORN".  WERE WRONG,,,,,,,,,,,  CUKOR ALWAYS THREW UP HIS HANDS WHEN HE DIDN'T GET HIS WAY,,, AND  BLAME IT ON SOMONE ELSE.  JUDY WOULD HAVE BEEN DIFFICULT TO DEAL WITH........ LET HER SING MORE,,,DO MORE,,,AND SHE DID,,, AND IT WASN'T AS GOOD A PICTURE. CUKOR ADED CONSTANCE BENNETT TO GARBO'S LAST FILM, "TWO FACED WOMAN".  GAVE BENNETT THE BETTER WRITTEN ROLE, AND PHOTOGRAPHED HER SO THAT SHE OUTSHINED GARBO.LANA DID NOT WANT TO WORK AT THIS TIME.  LANA WAS UNDER CONTRACT, AND THE STUDIO COULDN'T HAVE FOUND A LESS APPEALING ROLE IF THEY HAD TRIED. CUKOR LATER SAID THE FILM WAS A PACKAGE.  CUKOR HAD MEMORIES OF CONVERSATIONS.  EITHER MAYER AND CUKOR,, OR CUKOR AND DORY SCHERY.  LIKE THIS:  LANA'S FILMS ALWAYS MAKE MONEY.  CUKOR: "THERE IS ALWAYS A FIRST TIME WHEN THEY DON'T".  THE PACKAGE ALSO INCLUDED WENDALL COREY TO CO STAR IN "A LIFE OF HER OWN".  LANA REFUSED THE COREY IDEA, AND RAY MILLAND TOOK OVER.GRUNGY BLACK AND WHITE OPENING WITH THE UNLUCKY LETTERS,,,,,,,,,,, OF TWO FACED WOMAN ALPABET STYLE OF PRINTING FILL UP THE SCREEN,,,, THE MUSIC IS NOT HELPING.  LANA GETS OUT OF A TAXI,,,, AND SAYS "SEE YA CHARLIE"...... SHE GETS ON A TRAIN.WHEN SHE GETS TO THE MODELS OFFICE.... GOOD OLD GEORGE PHOTOGRAPH'S LANA SO THAT ANOTHER WHITER THINER, AND YOUNGER BLOND,, IN BLACK RIM GLASSES SITS ABOVE LANA.  NULL AND VOIDING ANY IMPACT LANA MIGHT HAVE HAD ON THE VIEWER, AS A POTENTIAL NUMBER ONE MODEL.  CUKOR WAS A DEVIL WITH THIS.  LOOK AT HOW MANY TIMES HE PHOTOGRAPHED PAULETTE GODDARD IN THE ROLE OF SCARLET.HE NEARLY KILLED MARYLIN MONROE,,, OR DID?  IN  "SOMETHINGS GOTTA GIVE".  FOX RELEASED ENOUGH OF IT,,,TO PUT TO REST THE IDEA THAT MARYLIN COULDN'T WORK.  AND CYD CHARISE IS SUCH A PRESENCE IN WHAT REMAINS.  CRITICS PRAISE ANN DVORAKS ACTING AND HER ROLE IN "A LIFE OF HER OWN" AS SHE PORTRAYED THE AGING MODEL.  ORIGINALLY LANA'S CHARACTER WAS SUPPOSED TO END IN A SIMILAR WAY.  ALL THESE PLANS WENT OUT THE WINDOW, AS THE PREVIEWS OF THE FILM DID NOT GO WELL.  SO IT SEEMS THEY STARTED FIDDLING AROUND WITH IT, VOILA!CUKOR MADE SURE THAT LANA WAS NOT LANA................  THE SCENE WITH RAY MILLAND WHERE SHE IS SLEEPING, IS NOT A PRETTY SIGHT.  LANA DOESN'T KNOW THAT HE IS THERE,,,,, WAKES UP TO FIND HIM LOOKING AT HER,,, AND ASKS IN A VERY PISSED OFF WAY,,, HAVEN'T YOU EVER SEEN A LADY PUT ON HER SHOES BEFORE?  SHE ISN'T FLATTERING HERE,,, AND IT IS GOOD.  SOON WE SEE LANA TURNER IN A WAY WE MAY NEVER SEE HER AGAIN.  AFTER LEAVING OFF HER GUY AT THE AIRPORT SHE LEAVES AND HAS TO GO UNDER A TUNNEL AND LANA'S EMOTIONS OVERCOME HER,HER FACE DISSOLVES IN TO A VERY UNFLATTERING SIGHT.  LANA WAS NEVER SO UGLY, NOR SO RIGHT IN HER ACTING.AS I STATED ABOVE, THE ENDING WAS CHANGED.  MANY TIMES.  WOULD THAT SOME OF THE CUT STUFF COULD BE PUT BACK,,,, AND WE COULD JUDGE.??THERE GOT TO BE A POINT WHERE PEOPLE DIDN'T LIKE LANA.  YET PAYED TO SEE HER MOVIES.  "THE FLAME AND THE FLESH", 1954, IS PROBABLY LOST AS A COLOR PRINT.  I HAVE SEEN A BOOTLEGED 10% OF GOOD VISION.  MOSTLY GREEN COLORS,,, THOUGH THE SOUND WAS GOOD ENOUGH TO GET AN IDEA.  FIX THE PRINT BEFORE IT'S TOO LATE, AND LET US LOOK AT IT,  THE MUSIC WAS WONDERFUL.,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  HAD MGM ALLOWED THE ORIGINAL ENDING.  THE STUDIO MIGHT HAVE HAD TO GIVE HER AN ACADEMY AWARD NOMINATION.  NO I WILL NOT SAY WHAT THE ORIGINAL INTENTION MIGHT HAVE BEEN,I HAVE ALREADY HINTED AT IT ABOVE.AT THE END,,,,LILLY FINDS HER WAY UP,,,UP,, THE STREET.  ...................................... DO NOT BE PISSED AT ME.  MGM DIDN'T LIKE THE ENDINGS.  THEY WANTED A LANA TURNER ENDING........ THE MUSIC MAY KEEP THIS FILM CURRENT.  ROSEMARY CLOONEY DOES A WONDERFUL JOB OF IT.  YOU MAY............. OFTEN HEAR IT IN AN ELEVATOR,,,,,, OR A PLACE.  MICHAEL FEINSTEIN DOES AN AWSOME RENDITION OF IT.SO AT THE END WHERE ARE WE?  I ENJOY THE MOVIE, AND JUST BOUGHT MY SECOND COPY.  I ENJOY THE MOVIE FOR ALL THE FAULTS.  I APPRECIATE LANA' ATTEMPT AT TRYING TO BE BETTER THAN SHE WAS.  THERE IS SOMETHING DARK AND STICKY ABOUT ALL THE CHARACTERS IN THE FILM.  WELL LET US SAY THAT THE MODELLING BUSINESS IS PROBABLY NOT THE PRETTY PLACE THAT SOME WANT TO SEE.  IT SEEMS CORRECT THAT IF YOU ARE GOING TO MAKE LANA A MODEL,,, AND EXPLORE THE BUSINESS OF BEING A MODEL,,, THEN WHY BOTHER TO MAKE THE FILM IF YOU CAN NOT FULLY TELL THE STORY.SHOULD LANA SPRING IN TO YOUR MIND........ FOR SOME CRAZY REASON,  GOOD. WATCH THE MOVIE.  AND THINK AS ALL THAT IS GOING ON............  LANA TURNER NEVER LET THE VIEWER DOWN.GLAMOUR. POISE. MANNERS!  =========  TRAGEDY, NIGHTMARES, LOSS.  ............... WATCH THE FILM.  A FADING FAST AVAILABLE MOVIE, OF THE CLASSIC ERA................ LANA GETS FIVE STARS FROM ME,,,, THE MOVIE ONE SHORT,,, STILL A VERY INTERESTING PICTURE.
summary: a fight to get the last star
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 1950 soap opera is not one of Lana Turner's best-known films but it is one of her best movies.  This glossy king-sized film literally opened a new era and new career for Lana, no longer the sweater girl of the forties but now a mature but still glamorous woman specializing in lush morality plays, reaching her apex in the genre at the end of the decade with PEYTON PLACE and IMITATION OF LIFE.  A LIFE OF HER OWN is very much in the tradition of those films but had the added bonus of having the legendary director George Cukor at the helm who gives this story more taste and discretion than the somewhat overrated Douglas Sirk in similiar, more celebrated  films.  Lana stars as a small-town girl who comes to New York with a letter of introduction to a major modeling agency, there she befriends fading model Ann Dvorak who briefly (VERY briefly) takes Lana under her wing.  Lana rises quickly to the top of the modeling game and finds herself in a fling with married businessman Ray Milland that isn't so easy to shake off.This movie is a very engrossing soap with fine performances by  Turner and Milland and a showy if brief supporting turn by 1930's starlet Ann Dvorak as a boozing glamour girl on the way out (note the remarkably discreet scene where she bangs on the door of a neighborhood pharmacy after closing hours for "cigarettes" and emerges with not only a carton of smokes but a mysterious second package suggesting liquour was not her only vice.)  Also featured in smallish but well played parts are Tom Ewell (in a rare non-comic role), Jean Hagen, and Barry Sullivan, suprisingly successful playing a sleazy playboy.  While no classic, "A Life of Her Own" is a remarkable production with a talented cast and director making a truly human story that might have been lurid and false in less capable hands.
summary: Turner and Milland in a Fine George Cukor soaper
